column2:
he’ll never leave.
Bram finds his way back to the chair and settles in.
Outside
column3: a bird cries out as the moon comes and goes behind thick clouds. He retrieves the pocket watch from his coat and curses. He forgot to wind it
column4: and the hands ceased their journey at 4:30. He stuffs it back into his pocket.

column1: 0430|4:30 A.M.|What has happened to me? Why am I so alone in the world? 4:30 A.M.—The solution came to me
column2: just as I was dozing off. Illuminated! Everything fits together
column3: and I see what I should have known from the beginning. No more sleep. I’ve got to get back to the lab and test this against the results from the computer. This
column5: is the flaw in the experiment. I’ve found it.

column1: 0430|four thirty in the morning|Algernon died two days ago. I found him at four thirty in the morning when I came back to the lab after wandering around down at the waterfront—on his side
column2: stretched out in the corner of his cage. As if he were running in his sleep.

column1: 0430|Four thirty|Jonas rolls painfully out of the hammock
column2: his aching lower back stiff and swollen
column3: in desperate need of a chiropractor. He checks his watch. Four thirty…but is it a.m. or p.m.?

column1:
0430|four-thirty|𝘛𝘩𝘦𝘯 𝘸𝘩𝘺 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘥𝘦𝘴𝘤𝘳𝘪𝘣𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 “𝘤𝘺𝘤𝘭𝘦”?
If you wish. A server is woken at hour four-thirty by stimulin in the airflow
column2: then yellow-up in our dormroom. After a minute in the hygiener and steamer
column3: we put on fresh uniforms before filing into the restaurant.

column1:
0430|four thirty in the morning|“What time is it? Do you have time here?”
“Of course we do.” She pulled up her sleeve
column2:
revealing a yellow Timex wristwatch. “It is four thirty in the morning.”
“That’s a nice watch.”
“My father gave it to me

column1: 0430|four thirty|At the end of a relationship
column2: it is the one who is not in love who makes the tender speeches. I was overwhelmed by a sense of betrayal
column3: betrayal because a union in which I had invested so much had been declared bankrupt without my feeling it to be so. Chloe had not given it a chance
column5: knowing the hopelessness of these inner courts announcing hollow verdicts at four thirty in the morning.

column1: 0430|0430|Hester Thrale undulates in in a false fox jacket at 2330 as usual even though she has to be up at like 0430 for the breakfast shift at the Provident Nursing Home and sometimes eats breakfast with Gately
column2: both their faces nodding perilously close to their Frosted Flakes.
